column1: Benicia ( bə-NEE-shə; bə-NI-shə; Spanish pronunciation: [beˈnisja]) is a waterside city in Solano County
column2: California
column3: located in the North Bay region of the San Francisco Bay Area. It served as the state capital for nearly thirteen months from 1853 to 1854.  The population was 26
column4: 997 at the 2010 census. The city is located along the north bank of the Carquinez Strait. Benicia is just east of Vallejo and across the strait from Martinez. Elizabeth Patterson has served as Mayor of Benicia since 2007.

column1: The town is divided into four areas: the East Side (east of First Street)
column2: the West Side (west of First Street)
column3: Southampton (north of Interstate 780)
column4: and the industrial park. Most of the town's older homes are on the east and west sides.  Southampton contains primarily single-family housing developments and condominiums
column5: most of which were built between 1970 and 2000.  The East Side includes the Benicia Arsenal
column6: a former United States Army armory
column7: which was bought by the city and is now used for a variety of purposes
column8: most notably as live-work spaces for artists.  The Arsenal is home to several historic (ca. 1860) landmark buildings such as The Clocktower
column10: and the Lieutenant's Quarters (currently known as Jefferson Street Mansion). The industrial park lies to the northeast of the residential areas of the city
column11: and includes the Valero oil refinery. The Benicia State Recreation Area is on the far west edge of the city.

column1: The main retail area in Benicia is First Street
column2: which attracts out-of-town antique and boutique shoppers and those seeking small-town
column3: historic charm.  In 1987 Benicia was selected to participate in the California Main Street Program.Connections to Benicia include Interstate 680 from Martinez to the south and Cordelia Junction (Fairfield) to the north
column6: and other local roads from Vallejo to the west.  Amtrak also runs through the city north towards Sacramento
column7: but the nearest train station lies in Martinez across the Carquinez Strait.  Railroad tracks carrying Amtrak and Union Pacific Railroad lines cross the strait alongside the Benicia–Martinez Bridge.

column1: The City of Benicia was founded on May 19
column3: by Dr. Robert Semple
column5: and Comandante General Mariano Guadalupe Vallejo
column6: on land sold to them by General Vallejo in December 1846. It was named for the General's wife
column7: Francisca Benicia Carillo de Vallejo. The General intended that the city be named "Francisca" after his wife
column8: but this name was dropped when the former city of "Yerba Buena" changed its name to "San Francisco
column9: so her second given name was used instead. In his memoirs, William Tecumseh Sherman contended that Benicia was the best natural site for a commercial city" in the region. It is said that in 1848 first word of gold found at Sutter's Mill was leaked at a Benicia Tavern thus starting the Gold Rush. Benicia became a way station on the way to the Sierras.Benicia was the third site selected to serve as the California state capital
column10: and its newly constructed city hall was California's capitol from February 11
column13: 1854. Soon after the legislature was moved to the courthouse in Sacramento
column14: which has remained the state capital ever since. The restored capitol is part of the Benicia Capitol State Historic Park
column15: and is the only building remaining of the state's early capitols
column16: which were in San Jose and Vallejo. Benicia was also the county seat of Solano County until 1858
column17: when that was moved to Fairfield.

column1: The original campus of Mills College was founded in Benicia in 1852 as the Young Ladies Seminary
column2: and was the first women's college west of the Rocky Mountains. Before moving to Oakland in 1871
column3: it was located on West I Street
the legendary prize fight between James J. Corbett and Joe Choynski was held on a barge off the coast of Benicia. The match lasted 28 rounds
column4: and is now commemorated by a plaque near Southampton Bay.

column2: Benicia was indirectly involved in the Pony Express. When riders missed their connection with a steamer in Sacramento
column3: they would continue on to Benicia and cross over to Martinez via the ferry. One of the earliest companies in California
column5: established a major shipyard in Benicia in the 19th century.  The prolific shipbuilder Matthew Turner formed the Matthew Turner Shipyard at Benicia in 1883.

column1: Benicia became an important wheat storage and shipping site. It was also the site of the United States Army's Benicia Arsenal.

column2: the Central Pacific Railroad rerouted the Sacramento-Oakland portion of its transcontinental line
column3: establishing a major railroad ferry across the Carquinez Strait from Benicia to Port Costa. The world's largest ferry
column5: later joined by the even larger Contra Costa
column6: carried entire trains across the Carquinez Strait from Benicia to Port Costa
column7: from whence they continued on to the Oakland Pier.In 1901
column8: the world's first long-distance powerline crossing over Carquinez Strait was built. After California's wheat output dropped in the early 20th century and especially after the Southern Pacific (which took over the operations of the Central Pacific) constructed a railroad bridge at Martinez in 1930 to replace the ferry crossing
column9: Benicia declined  until the economic boom of World War II
column10: which doubled the population to about 7

column7: now a historical landmark. A roof fire was quickly extinguished and the structure was not badly damaged. Losses were estimated at $125
column8: 000.Two developments in the early 1960s would completely change Benicia: The closing of the Benicia Arsenal in 1960–64
column9: and the completion of the Benicia–Martinez Bridge in 1962. The closing of the Arsenal removed Benicia's traditional economic base
column10: but allowed city leaders to create an industrial park on Arsenal land which eventually provided more revenue for the city than the Army had. The completion of the Benicia-Martinez Bridge made it possible for the city to become a suburb of San Francisco and Oakland
column11: and suburban development in the Benicia hills began in the late 1960s.

column1: Arts Benicia is a community-based non-profit organization whose mission is to stimulate
column2: educate
column3: and nurture cultural life in Benicia primarily through the visual arts. They provide exhibitions
column5: and classes that support artists and engage the broader community.

column1: The organization offers dynamic year-round art exhibitions and public art openings
column2: the Benicia Artists Open Studios event in the spring
column3: the Annual Benefit Art Auction in the fall
column5: and quarterly art classes for adults and kids. It is located in the Benicia Arsenal at 991 Tyler Street
column7: 12:00-5:00 PM during exhibitions; gallery admission is free to the public.

column1: Arts in the Park is an annual summer art celebration held in Benicia City Park.
One of the largest street fairs in Northern California
column2: this outdoor event began in 1963 with a few collectable and antique stores displaying their items on tables outside St. Paul's Church. Today
column3: over 300 antique and collectable dealers as well as other vendors display their wares in booths that span approximately 11 blocks of First Street. Unverified sources cite attendance in 2006 at approximately 20
column4: 000.  This event is sponsored by St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Benicia.

column2: there is a large community picnic at Benicia's City Park traditionally starting at noon.  Shortly after dark (approximately 9pm)
column3: there is a fireworks display that originates at the foot of First Street.

column2: Benicia's Fourth of July parade stretches all the way down First Street and typically includes music
column3: dancing

column1: Benicia is an active sailing community. In addition to individual sailing out of the Benicia Marina
column2: there are several organized events and competitions. During the summer months
column3: there is a yacht racing competition on Thursday evenings sponsored by the Benicia Yacht Club. The Yacht Club co-sponsors the annual Jazz Cup regatta with the South Beach Yacht Club
column4: and also sponsors a Youth Sailing Program that offers extensive training.

column1: On the fourth Sunday in July
column2: the Portuguese community in Benicia celebrates the feast of the Holy Ghost
column3: continuing a devotion established by the Queen St. Isabel of Portugal
column4: who was noted for her care for the poor. The festival starts with a parade to St. Dominic's Church followed by Mass
column5: followed by an auction and a dance. The Holy Ghost Parade celebrated 100 years in Benicia in 2007.

column1: Benicia is a Tree City USA and holds an annual Arbor Day event. The Benicia Tree Foundation hosts regular events that involve community members in tree-planting activities.
According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 15.7 square miles (41 km2)
column3: of which 12.9 square miles (33 km2) are land and 2.8 square miles (7.3 km2) (17.75%) are water. Benicia is located on the north side of the Carquinez Strait.
